* * Knowledge and attitude towards clinical governance (Clinical governance is a system through which health organizations are accountable for continuously improving the quality of their services and safeguarding high standards of care. It includes components like clinical effectiveness, audit, risk management, etc.)
    * Senior managers' knowledge and positive attitude towards Clinical Governance (Senior managers' understanding and support for Clinical Governance are crucial for its successful implementation. Their knowledge and attitude positively influence their enthusiasm and optimism towards the program.)
* * Organizational culture and structure (A supportive culture and appropriate organizational structure are perceived as facilitators for Clinical Governance implementation. A culture that promotes continuous improvement, openness, and teamwork, along with clear organizational roles and responsibilities, are essential. Continuous meetings and organizational commitment to Clinical Governance are also important.)
* * Managerial commitment and involvement (Managerial commitment and involvement are crucial for the success of Clinical Governance. Managers should demonstrate executive capabilities, provide adequate resources, and remove obstacles. Stability in managerial positions is also important for the continuity of the program.)
* * Staff engagement and resource allocation (Engagement of medical staff and allocation of adequate resources are identified as barriers to Clinical Governance implementation. Staff resistance due to high workload and lack of resources are significant challenges. Encouraging staff involvement and providing incentives are suggested as solutions.)
* * Legal challenges and parallel programs (Legal challenges and the existence of parallel quality improvement models are barriers to Clinical Governance implementation. Overcoming these barriers requires effective communication, strategic planning, and resource management.)
* * Time constraints and workload (Time constraints and competing responsibilities are barriers to Clinical Governance implementation. Addressing these barriers requires effective time management and prioritization of tasks.)
* * Need for training and education (Training and education are necessary to raise staff awareness and understanding of Clinical Governance. Continuous training can foster a positive attitude towards the program.)

<summary>
    • Orally dissolving strips are an advanced form of oral solid dosage form offering flexibility and comfort for patients.
        • They dissolve rapidly in the oral cavity, providing quick absorption and bioavailability.
        • Suitable for patients with swallowing difficulties, such as children, geriatrics, and those with acute allergic reactions.
    • The study aimed to develop an optimized orally dissolving strip of clobazam using pva and ssg polymers.
        • A 3 factorial design evaluated the effects of pva and ssg on film properties, disintegration time, and drug release.
        • The optimized formulation (f6) showed rapid disintegration, satisfactory tensile strength, and high drug release rate.
    • In vitro studies confirmed the formulation's dissolution rate, disintegration time, and drug release profile.
        • The formulation followed a diffusion-controlled release mechanism, aligning with the higuchi model.
        • The in vitro-in vivo correlation showed a strong relationship between drug release and absorption.
    • In vivo studies in rabbits indicated comparable pharmacokinetic profiles between the optimized strip and a marketed tablet.
        • The optimized strip demonstrated good stability over 6 months at 40°C and 75% relative humidity.
        • The study concluded that the optimized orally dissolving strip formulation of clobazam could be a convenient alternative to fast dissolving tablets for epilepsy treatment.
</summary>

<summary>
* The systematic review identifies limitations in the outcome measures used to evaluate stroke self-management interventions ( SMIs).
    * The majority of measures do not specifically target self-management as a discrete concept.
        * This reflects the difficulty in conceptualizing and operationalizing self-management in stroke.
        * The heterogeneity of measures suggests challenges in determining expected outcomes of SMIs.
        * The lack of consensus on appropriate measures and observed changes post-SMI indicates imprecise causal mechanisms.
        * There is a need for conceptualization of stroke self-management to identify appropriate outcomes and develop robust measures for evaluation.
</summary>

<summary>
* Objective: To assess the correlation between the Knee Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (koos) and objective measures in knee osteoarthritis patients.
    * Sub-objective: To compare the correlation strength of koos with the 6-minute walk test (6-mwt), age, height, weight, and body mass index (bmi).
* Methods: A cross-sectional study was conducted with 251 knee osteoarthritis patients.
    * Sub-methods: Data on koos subscales and objective measures were collected and analyzed using Spearman rank correlation.
* Results:
    * * Weak correlation was found between koos subscales and height.
        * Strong correlation was observed between koos subscales and weight/bmi.
    * * The 6-minute walk test had a weak correlation with koos-ADL subscale and strong correlations with koos-symptom, koos-pain, and koos-sports subscales.
        * BMI had a strong correlation with koos-pain, koos-symptom, koos-ADL, and koos-sports subscales.
        * Age had a weak correlation with koos-QOL subscale.
* Conclusion:
    * * The study confirms the use of koos in assessing knee osteoarthritis patients in India.
        * Objective measures like 6-mwt, weight, and bmi are strongly correlated with subjective koos scores.
        * Age has a weak correlation with koos-QOL subscale.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study investigates the impact of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy on inflammatory processes in rats.
        • High-fat diet and ovariectomy independently affect body weight and metabolic efficiency.
            • Combined, they increase body weight gain and carcass lipid content.
            • Hyperleptinemia is observed in ovariectomized rats on a high-fat diet.
            • Decreased levels of anti-inflammatory cytokines (il-6, il-10) and increased proinflammatory cytokines (tnf- and il-6) in adipose tissues are noted.
            • Tlr-4 protein content remains unchanged across groups.
        • Ovariectomy alone does not alter cytokine content in liver, muscle, or adipose tissues.
            • A high-fat diet decreases anti-inflammatory cytokines in adipose tissues.
            • Ovariectomy combined with a high-fat diet decreases tnf- in adipose tissues.
            • Tlr-4 protein content is consistent across all tissues and groups.
</summary>

<summary>
    • Study purpose: To evaluate demographic characteristics, clinical features, imaging results, complications, and follow-up of patients undergoing bronchial artery embolization ( BAE) for hemoptysis.
        • Study design: Retrospective analysis of 344 cases at Tianjin Hospital from 2006 to 2013.
        • Patient demographics: 186 men and 158 women, average age 57 years, with acute/massive hemoptysis in 234 and chronic/recurrent in 110.
        • Imaging findings: 30.5% had blood lobe on CT, 36.2% had bleeding source in one lung, 43.3% had unusual film on both lungs, and 38.1% had left-side abnormalities on angiography.
        • Embolization details: 97.7% underwent BAE, 944 arteries involved, 1530 coils used, 96% immediate control, 17.7% recurrent within 1 month, 21.5% recurrent over 1 month, and 31.1% fever post-procedure.
        • Complications: Subintimal dissection, artery spasm, closure, and reflux of embolic material.
        • Outcomes: Immediate control in 96%, recurrence in 17.7%, fever in 31.1%, and death in 28 patients.
        • Conclusion: BAE is effective and safe for hemoptysis control, especially in non-operable patients, with a high immediate success rate and manageable complications.
</summary>

• The study aimed to explore the contribution of celiac disease (CD) and Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection to lymphocytic gastritis (LG) and to characterize the different immunoprofiles of the gastric inflammatory cells involved in these diseases.
	- The study found a high prevalence of LG in CD patients, with a lower rate in HP-infected patients.
	- Immunohistochemical analysis suggested that CD might contribute to LG through a higher count of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes, while HP infection did not significantly affect LG.

<summary>
    • Anti-VEGF therapies effectively decrease tumor size, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in orthotopic breast cancer models.
        • These therapies reduce tumor growth and microvessel density, and limit immune cell infiltration, including macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, and myeloid-derived suppressor cells.
        • Anti-VEGF therapies modulate intratumoral levels of IL-1 and CXCL1, correlating with changes in immune cell infiltration.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The revive survey reveals a significant lack of awareness and understanding of vaginal and vulvar atrophy ( VVA) among postmenopausal women, with many unaware that VVA is related to menopause and its symptoms are not self-resolving.
        • Despite the prevalence of VVA symptoms, only a small percentage of women have discussed these issues with healthcare providers, and when they have, the conversation was often not initiated by the healthcare provider.
            • The survey indicates that many women continue to use over-the-counter products despite inadequate symptom relief, highlighting the need for better communication and education about treatment options.
            • Women's preferences for treatment methods, such as oral versus vaginal therapies, and their concerns about side effects and convenience, suggest the importance of personalized treatment plans and patient involvement in decision-making.
</summary>

<summary>
* Maternal age, education, income, smoking, body mass index (BMI), and physical activity were associated with folic acid (FA) supplement use among Danish pregnancy planners.
* Higher age and completion of high school were positively associated with FA supplement use.
* Lower income, higher BMI, and less physical activity were negatively associated with FA supplement use.
* Women with a history of spontaneous abortion were more likely to use FA supplements.
* Women with unplanned pregnancies were less likely to use FA supplements.
* Compliance with FA supplement recommendations may be influenced by health consciousness and awareness of preconceptional guidelines.
* Targeting women at high risk of non-compliance, such as those with risky behaviors or chronic diseases, is important for public health interventions.
* Despite increased awareness and information availability, over one-third of pregnancy planners do not follow the preconceptional FA recommendation.
* The study suggests a need for more preconceptional guidance and support for women trying to conceive.
* Further research is needed to understand the barriers to FA supplement use and to develop effective strategies to improve compliance.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study aimed to evaluate lipid peroxidation parameters and total antioxidant capacity in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) before and after surgery, and compare these with patients receiving simvastatin therapy.
        • The study group consisted of PAD patients treated surgically or pharmacologically, with clinical parameters generally not differing significantly between groups.
            • Before surgery, PAD patients showed elevated mda levels, indicating high oxidative stress.
                • Statin therapy reduced mda concentrations in simvastatin-treated patients compared to PAD patients before surgery.
                    • Surgical treatment did not significantly decrease mda concentrations in PAD patients after surgery.
                    • A decrease in frap level was observed in PAD patients 35 and 710 days after surgery, suggesting a reduction in antioxidant status.
                    • Thiol group concentrations decreased 35 days postoperatively and increased 710 days after surgery, indicating oxidative stress fluctuations.
                    • Ceruloplasmin activity was influenced by both simvastatin therapy and surgical treatment, with increased activity observed 710 days postoperatively.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study investigates the effects of -aminoadipic acid ( aaa ) on retinal damage and neurodegeneration in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension ( aoh ) that mimics glaucoma.
    • Aaa treatment was found to protect against retinal abnormalities and apoptosis of retinal ganglion cells ( rgcs) in aoh rats.
        • Aaa attenuated gliosis in müller cells and downregulated tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( tnf-), suggesting a protective mechanism against neurodegeneration in glaucoma.
</summary>

* * the laparoscopy - assisted endoscopic full - thickness resection with ligation device ( laeftr - l ) is a promising technique for the treatment of nonampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms ( sdns).
* * it allows complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells or severe adverse events ( saes).
* * the mean operative time was 173 minutes, and the mean tumor size was 9 mm.
* * complete resection was achieved in all cases, and the procedure was completed without complications.
* * laeftr - l may be a promising technique for the treatment of nonampullary sdns which can achieve complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells or saes.
* * prospective studies are needed to further evaluate the efficacy and safety of laeftr - l procedures.

<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is an autosomal recessive condition caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis, with 90-95% due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD).
• CAH leads to cortisol deficiency, hypoaldosteronism, and hyperandrogenism, causing various signs and symptoms.
• CAH is classified into classic (salt-losing or non-salt-losing) and non-classic forms, with different clinical presentations and management strategies.
• Medical treatment for CAH includes glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration to suppress adrenal androgens and compensate for deficiencies.
• Four cases were reported, all diagnosed with CAH and managed with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone.
• Abdominal CT scans revealed adrenal masses in all four cases, with two undergoing adrenalectomy due to increasing size and virilization.
• Adrenal masses are common in CAH patients, with most being benign but small tumors prevalent in untreated cases.
• The pathogenesis of adrenal tumors in CAH patients is thought to be related to acth hypersecretion due to lack of glucocorticoid synthesis.
• Patients with CAH should maintain steroid medication to avoid adrenal tumor development, improve symptoms, and normalize electrolyte disorders.
• Long-term management of CAH requires a multidisciplinary approach involving paediatric, reproductive, adult endocrinologists, and clinical psychologists.
• Avoiding high steroid doses is crucial to prevent adrenal tumor development in CAH patients.
• Regular follow-up imaging can help detect adrenal tumors in patients with long-term management of CAH.
• CAH management has significantly improved over the past 50 years, with new medical strategies offering improved outcomes.
• Patients with CAH should maintain steroid medication to prevent adrenal tumor development and manage symptoms effectively.

    * The study examined the relationship between dietary and physical activity behaviors and self-rated health ( srh) in a diverse population in Miami, Florida.
        * The sample consisted of 1,701 adults, with a significant proportion of Hispanics and non-Hispanic blacks.
        * Females reported higher obesity rates, poorer srh, and less physical activity compared to males.
        * Lower fruit and vegetable intake and higher fat intake were associated with poorer srh in both genders.
        * Physical activity was significantly associated with better srh in females, but the association was not significant in males after adjusting for covariates.

* * The study aimed to quantify the impact of bone metastasis ( BM) and skeletal - related events ( SREs) on mortality among elderly lung cancer patients.
* * The study used data from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program and the Medicare claims database.
* * A cohort of patients aged 65 years or older with a new diagnosis of lung cancer between July 1, 1999, and December 31, 2005, was identified.
* * Bone metastasis and SREs were determined based on Medicare claims data, and mortality was assessed through December 31, 2006.
* * The study found that 21% of patients had evidence of bone metastasis within one year post lung cancer diagnosis, and 51% had SREs.
* * Mortality was higher among patients with bone metastasis (HR: 2.4) compared to those without (HR: 1.9).
* * The association between bone metastasis and mortality was similar for patients with and without SREs.
* * The study also found that SREs were common among patients with bone metastasis, with 81% receiving radiotherapy to bone.
* * The most common site of pathological fracture was the spine, followed by the hip, femur, humerus, and distal radius/ulna.
* * The study concluded that bone metastasis was associated with mortality among lung cancer patients, regardless of the presence of SREs.
* * The study's limitations included the use of Medicare data, which excluded patients under 65, those with only Medicare part A coverage, and those in non-SEER areas.
* * The study also noted the potential for false positives in identifying bone metastasis and the possibility of unmeasured confounding factors.
* * The study suggested that further research is needed to validate the procedures used to identify bone metastasis and to explore the impact of functional status on outcomes.
* * The study highlighted the importance of early detection and management of bone metastasis in lung cancer patients.
* *

<summary>
    • The human gut microbiota has been linked to various physiological traits and diseases.
        • The gut microbiota can influence liver function, glucose metabolism, and behavior.
            • Gut microbiota has been associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
            • Gut microbiota can affect central nervous system (CNS) function and behavior.
    • The gut microbiota's role in obesity and metabolic diseases is complex and multifactorial.
        • Germ-free mice show resistance to diet-induced obesity.
            • Specific bacterial species can influence host adiposity and metabolism.
            • The gut microbiota can interact with host tissues and influence gene expression.
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is associated with altered microbial composition and reduced diversity.
        • Genetic mutations and environmental factors contribute to IBD pathogenesis.
            • Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and nod-like receptors (NLRs) play roles in gut immunity and IBD.
            • Bacterial species like prevotella and bacteroidetes are associated with IBD.
            • The microbiota may influence the development of colorectal cancer (CRC).
    • The gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem with significant interindividual variability.
        • The gut microbiota is influenced by diet, genetics, and environment.
            • Dietary changes can shift the gut microbiota composition.
            • Antibiotics and processed foods can reduce microbial diversity.
            • The gut microbiota may have a role in disease susceptibility and prevention.
            • Probiotics may modulate the gut microbiota and improve health.
</summary>

<summary>
    • Study aimed to improve clinical response in non-responders to cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) by identifying optimal left ventricular (LV) pacing sites through acute haemodynamic studies.
    • Involved 24 clinical non-responders to CRT, with various ECG morphologies and NYHA classifications.
    • Utilized a 6f multipurpose angioplasty guiding catheter for endocardial pacing and LVdp/dtmax measurements.
    • Positive haemodynamic response (HR) defined as a 15% increase in LVdp/dtmax from baseline.
    • Found that LV endocardial pacing at optimal sites (longest q-lv interval) improved HR in 12 out of 14 patients.
    • Patients with apical coronary sinus lead position showed no significant HR improvement with LV endocardial pacing.
    • Five patients with apical lead position showed a substantial HR increase (>15%) with LV endocardial pacing, justifying lead upgrade.
    • Ten patients considered possible candidates for LV endocardial pacing; five agreed to implantation, improving clinically after 6 months.
    • No significant difference in LVdp/dtmax between coronary sinus and LV endocardial pacing sites.
    • Longest q-lv interval was a reliable indicator for optimal electrode position in individual patients.
    • LV endocardial pacing opposite epicardial sites did not show acute HR improvement.
    • Study suggests LV endocardial pacing opposite epicardial sites as a potential alternative to LV endocardial lead placement.
    • Larger randomized studies needed to justify LV endocardial pacing as an alternative to epicardial pacing.
</summary>

* * mouse lifespan , weight , and food consumption were monitored as described previously .
    * two hundred ninety - seven control mice were shifted to daily feeding with an identical quantity of control diet supplemented with ndga at various doses per kg diet .
    * food consumption and health were monitored at the time of feeding , and any uneaten food noted .
    * the mice had ad libitum access to tap water , which was acidified to reduce colonization by pseudomonas .
    * the health of the mice was examined twice daily by laboratory staff and weekly by a veterinarian .
    * this study was approved by the institutional animal care and use committee at the university of california , riverside .
* * the effect of ndga on fpa plaque size was determined as described previously .
    * one day old male flies were exposed to 3 mm ndga in dmso or vehicle treatments in 9525 mm glass vials for 3 days .
    * after 3 days , movement of the flies was monitored for 72 hours using a trikinetics locomotor activity monitor .
    * means  sem were calculated for 30 minutes time increments over the entire 72 hour trial ( 144 recordings ) .
    * an unpaired , two - sample t test was used to determine the significance of differences between experimental and control treatments .
* * the effect of ndga on locomotor activity was determined as described previously .
    * male mice were fed ndga in their food at various doses per kg diet .
    * locomotor activity was quantified using a lam 32 activity monitor .
    * there was no significant difference between the activity of flies consuming food containing ndga or an equivalent volume of vehicle .
* * male mice were fed ndga in their food at various doses per kg diet .
    * food consumption was determined by totaling the amount eaten by each treatment group during each time period , adjusted for the number of mice .
    * the mice ate essentially all their food each day , with the exception of a single excursion by the 1.5g / kg diet group late in life

<summary>
* Biomarkers are crucial for personalized medicine, influencing disease susceptibility and treatment response.
* Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified genetic variants for complex diseases and pharmacogenetic markers.
* Personalized medicine applications extend beyond drug selection to include withholding treatment, preventive interventions, and targeted treatment options.
* Biomarkers are defined as measurable substances or structures indicating normal processes, pathogenic processes, or therapeutic responses.
* Biomarkers are classified into dna biomarkers, dna tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers, each with distinct characteristics and applications.
* Dna biomarkers are stable, reproducible, and suitable for prospective validation, but not for treatment monitoring or pharmacodynamics.
* Biomarker validation studies follow a multi-phase approach, including discovery, assay development and validation, retrospective validation, prospective validation, and randomized controlled trials.
* The utility of biomarkers in clinical routine depends on their applicability, ease of measurement, and acceptance by clinicians.
* Reporting guidelines like STARD, REMARK, and PRISMA improve the quality of biomarker studies and facilitate understanding and acceptance of research findings.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study utilized tethered particle microscopy (tpm) to measure the flexural stiffness of myosin Va (myoVa) and its subdomains, providing insights into the structural components critical to its functional capacities.
• The findings suggest that the lever arms must be rigid enough to allow intramolecular strains to be communicated between heads for proper gating and control of the motor's processivity, while the lever arm/rod junction must be highly compliant to enable myoVa to maneuver through actin networks and deliver cargo efficiently.
    • The lever arm flexural stiffness was estimated to be 0.0346 pN/nm, with a corresponding persistence length of 242 nm.
    • The distal rod segment was found to have a flexural stiffness of 0.0326 pN/nm, suggesting a structure composed of a long coiled-coil segment or a series of coiled-coil segments interspersed with compliant disordered segments.
    • The myoVa-hmm and myoVa-fl constructs exhibited significantly lower flexural stiffness than the lever arms and rod segments, indicating that the lever arm/rod junction must be highly compliant.
</summary>

<summary>
* *
    * The study aimed to determine if functional polymorphisms in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes could predict clinical outcomes in esophageal cancer patients post-surgery.
        * The researchers genotyped six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 346 patients undergoing surgical resection for esophageal cancer.
        * No significant associations were found between the SNPs and disease-free survival (DFS) in patients with esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) in univariate analysis.
* *
    * However, in multivariate analysis, EAC patients with the heterozygous mdm2 t/g genotype had a significantly improved DFS compared to wild-type t/t genotype.
        * Patients with EAC carrying the homozygous cdh1 g/g genotype had a significantly reduced survival compared to wild-type g/g genotype.
* *
    * The mdm2 t/g genotype may confer a survival benefit in EAC patients, possibly due to its interaction with tumor p53 status.
        * The cdh1 g/g genotype may increase the risk of disease recurrence in EAC patients by suppressing cdh1 expression and impairing cell adhesion.
* *
    * The study suggests that genetic variations can impact DFS in EAC patients, indicating the potential for using genetic markers to predict outcomes and guide treatment.
        * Further prospective studies are needed to validate these associations and explore the prognostic significance of these genetic variants.
* *
</summary>

<summary>
    • Study design: Descriptive and analytical cross-sectional study over 2 years with quantitative data collection methods.
        • Participants: 50 consenting patients from the odontology unit of Saint-Antoine hospital.
        • Data collection: Medical history, physical examination, socio-demographic characteristics, socio-behavioral factors, laboratory tests.
        • Diagnosis: Based on European Community Clearinghouse guidelines for presumptive diagnosis of OPC.
        • Candida identification: Conventional tests and species identification using germ tube test, chrom agar medium, and sugar assimilation tests.
        • CD4+ cell count analysis: Flow cytometer method, WHO classification.
</summary>

<summary>
    • Study findings:
        • Candida species isolated from oral cavity in 76% of patients.
            • C. albicans was the most frequent species (92%).
            • C. tropicalis and C. glabrata were less common (5.26% and 2.64%, respectively).
        • Distribution of oral lesions based on CD4+ count:
            • 62% of lesions occurred at CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm³.
            • 26% of lesions at CD4+ count of 201-499 cells/mm³.
            • 12% of lesions at CD4+ count > 500 cells/mm³.
        • Majority of patients with OPC had CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm³.
</summary>

<summary>
• Study evaluates performance of three different - sized superparamagnetic iron oxide ( spio ) tracers for sentinel lymph node biopsy ( slnb) in a porcine model.
    • Tracers: feraheme / rienso ( 32 nm), sienna+ ( 59 nm), and endorem / feridex ( 111 nm).
    • All tracers diluted to same iron concentration ( 11.2 mg fe / ml).
    • Hydrodynamic particle size: 32 nm, 59 nm, 111 nm.
    • Significant intratracer heterogeneity in particle size observed.
• All slnb procedures successful in identifying magnetic hotspots transcutaneously.
    • Increased number of procedures with successful hotspot identification over time for all tracers.
    • 59 nm tracer identified hotspots in all cases within 10 minutes, 111 nm tracer in all but one case at 240 minutes.
• Total of 77 slns identified with handheld magnetometer during surgery.
    • More slns identified with 32 nm tracer ( mean 2.9 ) compared to 111 nm ( mean 1.7 ) and 59 nm ( mean 1.8 ) tracers.
    • Statistically significant difference in the number of slns identified between tracers ( p<0.001).
• Ex vivo magnetometer counts and iron content of excised slns varied among tracers.
    • 59 nm tracer demonstrated significantly higher counts and iron content compared to 32 nm and 111 nm tracers.
    • Higher sensitivity of magnetometer for 59 nm tracer ( p<0.05).
• Iron content and distribution within excised slns varied among tracers.
    • 111 nm tracer deposited mainly within macrophages, 59 nm tracer displayed free iron granules peripherally.
    • 32 nm tracer showed sparse, small islands of iron within macrophages.
    • No difference in histop

<summary>
    • The study aimed to identify surrogate markers for complete healing in advanced diabetic foot ulcers (dfus) and assess their predictive value.
        • Surrogate markers included percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at 2nd week and end of treatment (eot).
    • Data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials and an active postmarketing surveillance were analyzed.
        • Granulation tissue development was the most efficient predictor of healing, with high sensitivity and specificity.
    • The proportion mediated by granulation tissue was very high, suggesting it significantly contributed to the final healing effect.
        • The effect of treatment on healing was lost when granulation tissue formation was included in the model, indicating its mediating role.
    • The study confirmed granulation tissue development as an early predictor of final healing in a postmarketing series.
        • Granulation tissue development can be used as a surrogate marker in clinical trials, potentially reducing the need to wait for complete re-epithelization.
        • The study provides evidence for the use of granulation tissue development as a predictor of wound healing in advanced dfus, with practical implications for clinical care and healthcare programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* The study compared the perioperative extent of surgical trauma and postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after needlescopic transabdominal preperitoneal ( ntapp ) and single-incision laparoscopic ( stapp ) mesh repairs for inguinal hernia.
* Eighty-five patients with uncomplicated inguinal hernias were retrospectively analyzed, with demographic and surgical data collected.
* The ntapp group had a significantly smaller umbilical skin incision (mean 13.4 mm vs. 27.3 mm) and shorter operative time (mean 54.8 min vs. 85.9 min).
* No hernia recurrence or port-site hernia was observed in either group.
* Immediate postoperative pain duration was longer in the stapp group (mean 5.6 days vs. 9.8 days).
* Stapp patients experienced greater wound pain intensity when resuming daily activities (mean 2.7 vs. 4.4).
* Seven stapp patients reported subjective deterioration in abdominal wall mobility, none in the ntapp group.
* Cosmetic satisfaction was high in both groups (vas score 9.7 vs. 9.6).
* The ntapp group had a significantly shorter mean period of sick leave (11.2 days vs. 24.1 days).
* Despite cessation of postoperative wound pain, 27 ntapp patients (54%) and 32 stapp patients (91.4%) remained on sick leave at follow-up (p = .045).
* The ntapp procedure offers distinct advantages in the immediate postoperative phase but comparable long-term results to stapp repair.
* Randomized controlled trials comparing ntapp, stapp, and conventional tapp repairs are needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic surgery.
* * The ntapp group had a significantly smaller umbilical skin incision and shorter operative time.
* * No hernia recurrence or port-site hernia was observed in either group.
* * Immediate postoperative pain duration was longer in the stapp group.

<summary>
    • The study aimed to verify the correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing pharyngeal tonsil hyperplasia in children with mouth breathing.
        • A significant regular and positive correlation (r = 0.52) was found between the two exams, indicating a relationship but not a perfect correlation.
            • Most children showed grade 2 and 3 hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils in nasopharyngoscopy, while cephalometry showed a tendency to underestimate the size of the pharyngeal tonsils.
            • Cephalometry had a sensitivity of 35% and a negative predictive value of 72% for diagnosing pharyngeal tonsil hyperplasia.
            • Nasopharyngoscopy is suggested when cephalometry results are negative in mouth-breathing patients due to its tridimensional and dynamic nature.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The incidence of ipsilateral breast tumor relapse ( ibtr) in patients previously treated for breast carcinoma is estimated to be less than 6%.
        • It is crucial to distinguish between true local recurrence (tr) and new primary tumor (npt) for proper clinical management.
            • Criteria for differentiation include tumor location, staging, histological subtype, and her-2 and hormone receptor expression.
            • True local recurrence (tr) is consistent with the natural progression of the disease, while new primary tumor (npt) arises from residual breast tissue.
            • Genetic sequencing is the best method to establish true clonality, but it's not yet standardized.
            • Salvage mastectomy is the standard treatment for ibtr, but its superiority compared to conservative surgery is not conclusively proven.
            • The prognosis and treatment for tr and npt differ significantly, with tr requiring more aggressive treatment and npt similar to de novo breast carcinoma.
            • Adjuvant tamoxifen may benefit patients with npt due to its effect on reducing recurrence.
            • Long-term follow-up is essential for breast cancer survivors to monitor for relapse patterns and establish appropriate care.
</summary>

<summary>
* * * * *
    * The study aimed to evaluate the change in pelli  robson log contrast sensitivity ( cs ) and central retinal thickness ( crt ) after switching from ranibizumab to aflibercept in patients with treatment-resistant neovascular age-related macular degeneration ( neovascular amd).
        * The study included 40 patients with persistent fluid on spectral domain optical coherence tomography ( sd - oct) despite previous ranibizumab treatment.
        * After switching to aflibercept, the mean cs increased from 1.32 to 1.40 log units ( p=0.00079), and the mean crt decreased from 354 to 332 micrometers ( p=0.004).
        * There was no significant change in mean best corrected visual acuity ( bcva ) from baseline to week 12.
        * The national eye institute 25-item visual function questionnaire ( nei vfq-25) showed an overall improvement in vision-related quality of life in 65% of patients.
* * * * *
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study aimed to evaluate the association between the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and multiple sclerosis ( MS) in an Iranian population.
        • A case-control study was conducted with 74 MS patients and 75 healthy controls.
            • The IL-25 gene was analyzed using PCR and RFLP techniques.
            • The chi-square test and logistic regression model were used for statistical analysis.
            • No significant association was found between the c424c/a polymorphism and MS.
        • The study concluded that the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene is not associated with MS in the Iranian population.
            • The study highlighted the need for further research on other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene and serum levels of IL-25.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study evaluated the prevalence of thoracic aortic aneurysm ( taa) and abdominal aortic aneurysm ( aaa) in a Korean population with multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease and coronary heart disease ( chd).
        • The study included 542 hypertensive male patients aged 65 years or older without a history of aortic aneurysm.
        • The prevalence of taa was 36.5%, and aaa was 6.0%.
        • Taa was associated with older age, larger body surface area, higher diastolic blood pressure, and absence of dyslipidemia.
        • Aaa was independently associated with dyslipidemia, smoking history, and presence of taa.
        • The prevalence of taa was higher than aaa in patients with a history of aaa.
        • The study suggests the need for distinct screening strategies for taa and aaa based on risk factors and ethnicity.
        • The study's limitations include the inability to accurately measure the aortic root using non-contrast CT and the population's high-risk status.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study aimed to evaluate the adequacy of endometrial samples obtained using the sap-1 device compared to dilation and curettage ( d & c) and hysteroscopic biopsy.
    • The study involved 1514 patients with endometrial carcinoma risk factors, with 375 undergoing d & c or hysteroscopy.
    • The sap-1 device provided more sufficient materials for cytology than d & c or hysteroscopic biopsy (p < 0.01).
    • Most patients experienced no pain during sap-1 sampling, claiming it was similar to the insertion of a cytobrush for cervical sampling.
    • The overall accuracy for detecting endometrial cancer, complex hyperplasia with atypia, and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia was 92.4%, with a sensitivity of 73%, specificity of 95.8%, positive prediction value of 75%, and negative prediction value of 95.3%.
    • The study suggests that the sap-1 sampler combined with the liquid-based surepath preparation method may become a reliable screening method for endometrial carcinoma and its precursors, especially in postmenopausal and asymptomatic women.
    • The main reasons for the study's lower accuracy compared to previous studies include patients with positive results undergoing further diagnostic procedures, and the need for additional methods to distinguish focal atypical endometrial lesions from benign lesions.
    • The study recommends further investigation using immunohistochemistry and biochemistry to improve the accuracy of endometrial cytology.
</summary>

<summary>
* Breast cancer remains a significant global health issue, with high incidence rates in Europe and North America.
    * Digital mammography (DM) has become the standard in the US, offering higher sensitivity and lower risk of image loss compared to film mammography (FM).
* Despite its benefits, conventional mammography can miss cancers in dense breast tissue, leading to false positives and unnecessary biopsies.
    * Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) and contrast-enhanced digital mammography (CEDM) are emerging technologies that may improve cancer detection and reduce false positives.
* DBT creates 3D images, potentially improving the recognition of abnormalities and reducing the need for additional imaging.
    * CEDM uses contrast medium to highlight malignant neovascularity, potentially offering MRI-like functional information with lower cost and radiation exposure.
* DBT and CEDM are undergoing further technological developments and clinical trials, with the potential to become integral parts of breast cancer screening programs.
    * These advancements aim to improve patient comfort, reduce radiation exposure, and enhance the accuracy of breast cancer detection.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study investigates the efficacy of diphenhydramine, a first-generation antihistamine, as an antitussive in subjects with acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI).
        • Subjects with URI symptoms were recruited and randomized to receive diphenhydramine, dextromethorphan, or placebo.
        • Cough reflex sensitivity was measured using capsaicin challenge testing 2 hours after drug administration.
        • The diphenhydramine-containing formulation significantly increased log cough reflex sensitivity (p < 0.01) compared to placebo.
        • The diphenhydramine-containing formulation was more effective than dextromethorphan in inhibiting cough reflex sensitivity.
        • The study suggests that diphenhydramine may be a more effective antitussive than dextromethorphan for acute URI.
        • Further clinical trials are needed to evaluate the efficacy of these over-the-counter (OTC) cough and cold medications.
</summary>

<summary>
    • Aging is associated with endothelial dysfunction, characterized by reduced nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability and increased vasoconstriction, hypercoagulation, and inflammation.
        • Oxidative stress and inflammation are prominent features of aging, leading to a chronic inflammatory state and endothelial dysfunction.
        • Exercise training prevents and restores age-related impairment of endothelial function, possibly by restoring NO availability and alleviating inflammation.
        • Exercise increases antioxidant defense mechanisms and reduces proinflammatory cytokines, improving endothelial function.
        • Exercise-induced NO production is upregulated by shear stress, which is increased during exercise.
        • Exercise training enhances the expression of endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) and superoxide dismutase (SOD), reducing oxidative stress and improving endothelial function.
        • Exercise training improves arterial compliance and reduces plasma endothelin-1 (ET-1) levels, further contributing to improved endothelial function.
        • Regular exercise reduces systemic inflammation and improves insulin sensitivity, which are beneficial for endothelial function.
        • Exercise training improves endothelial function in older adults, reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The number of metastatic lymph nodes and the lymph node ratio (LNR) are significant prognostic factors in breast carcinoma patients with axillary lymph node metastasis.
        • A significant difference in disease-free survival (DFS) and locoregional recurrence-free survival (LRFS) was observed between patients with 15 lymph nodes removed versus those with 6 or more lymph nodes removed.
        • The most significant LNR threshold values for DFS and LRFS were 0.20 and 0.30, respectively.
        • The LNR threshold value for distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) was 0.15, which had independent prognostic significance in cox analysis.
        • LNR had independent prognostic significance for DFS and LRFS, while the number of removed lymph nodes did not.
        • LNR can be used to separate patients with n1 disease into low- and high-risk groups for DMFS, regardless of the total number of lymph nodes removed.
        • LNR may be useful to standardize adjuvant therapy for patients operated in hospitals with different axillary dissection widths and median number of removed lymph nodes.
    • In patients with 10 or more lymph nodes removed, neither the number of removed lymph nodes nor LNR had prognostic significance for LRFS.
        • This suggests that in n1 disease, removal of at least 10 lymph nodes may be sufficient for locoregional control, and additional lymph node removal may not be related to LRFS.
        • Therefore, n1 disease may be homogeneous in terms of LRFS.
</summary>

<summary>
    • Enzymatic phosphorylation of alcohols using inorganic phosphate donors offers an efficient alternative to traditional methods with poor atom economy and waste generation.
        • Acid phosphatases from various bacterial sources were selected for their broad substrate scope and ability to transfer phosphate from inorganic donors to alcohols.
            • The enzymes tested included phonsf, phonse, piacp, and phytase, with phonse showing the highest activity for secondary alcohols.
            • The phosphorylation reactions were highly chemoselective for primary alcohols over secondary alcohols, and for primary over secondary hydroxyl groups.
            • The reactions were sensitive to reaction parameters such as pH and phosphate donor type, with polyphosphates providing higher yields than di- or triphosphates.
            • Immobilized enzymes on polymeric beads were successfully used for the synthesis of phosphate monoesters on a preparative scale, demonstrating the potential of enzymatic phosphorylation in synthetic chemistry.
</summary>

<summary>
* Invasion biology and management have faced criticism on various grounds, including the overestimation of problems, the potential for increased biodiversity, xenophobia, the impracticality of combating invasions, and the inhumane nature of eradication methods.
* Critics argue that most introduced species do not cause harm, that some can increase biodiversity, that opposition to invasions is xenophobic, that preventing invasions is futile in the face of globalization, and that eradication methods are inhumane.
* However, modern invasion biology recognizes the significant and growing impacts of introduced species, with studies showing ecosystem-level effects, hybridization, and lag effects.
* Research has shown that introduced species can cause harm, with about 30% of introduced terrestrial vertebrates and freshwater plants and animals known to have harmful impacts.
* The lag effect suggests that waiting for impacts to be recognized before acting is ill-advised, as populations may spread beyond control.
* Restoration ecology aims to re-establish historical ecosystem trajectories, not to recreate past conditions.
* Critics of novel ecosystems argue that they are undefined and that all ecosystems are constantly changing.
* Restoration ecology does not aim to return ecosystems to historical conditions but to re-establish their historical trajectories.
* The call for abandoning traditional restoration ecology in favor of novel ecosystems is based on misconceptions and lacks scientific and technological support.
* The contention that novel ecosystems are inevitable can delay prevention and redress of environmental impacts.
* Critics can slow the progress of invasion biology and restoration ecology by influencing policy and public perception.
* Despite criticisms, the field of invasion biology has made significant progress, and eradication and management efforts can be effective with the right techniques and political will.
* The technology for early detection, rapid response, and eradication of invasive species is improving, and there are successful examples of eradication and maintenance programs.
* The field of restoration ecology is growing and making progress, with increasing recognition of its importance and potential.
* Both invasion biology and restoration

<summary>
    • Schwannomas of the vidian canal are rare tumors that can cause significant morbidity due to nerve involvement or local mass effect.
        • These tumors can present with symptoms such as headaches, facial pain, facial muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, and nasal dryness, or may be incidentally found during imaging for other conditions.
        • Treatment options include surgical resection, radiation therapy, or conservative management, with the choice depending on various factors such as tumor size, location, and patient preference.
        • This case report discusses a 49-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis who presented with an incidental finding of a vidian canal schwannoma, which was managed with radiation therapy due to the patient's young age and the desire to minimize late normal tissue injury risks.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study compared the stiffness of short-segment pedicle fixation using monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws with or without an intermediate screw at the level of a burst fracture.
        • The addition of an intermediate screw decreased the range of motion (ROM) in all tested directions for both monoaxial and polyaxial screw groups.
            • The short-segment construct with intermediate screws had significantly increased ROM in flexion, extension, lateral bending, and torsion compared to the constructs without intermediate screws.
            • The short-segment construct with polyaxial screws had significantly greater ROM in flexion and extension compared to the construct with monoaxial screws.
            • The short-segment mps fixation group was significantly more stable in flexion and extension than the short-segment pps fixation group.
</summary>

<summary>
    • The electrodeposition of CuSnS2 (cushion) thin films with Rhodamine B (Rb) as a structure-directing agent (S.D.A.) and its subsequent removal by dimethylacetamide (DMA) treatment results in highly porous and crystalline films.
        • The crystallographic orientation and porosity of the films can be controlled by varying the concentration of Rb in the electrodeposition bath.
            • The resulting porous cushion films exhibit dye-sensitized photocathodic properties, showing potential for use in tandem dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).
</summary>

<summary>
    • The nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut, believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication that normally disappears during the second month of intrauterine development.
        • Tornwaldt's cyst develops if the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed (cystic type) or if crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction (crust type).
        • The crust type of bursitis presents with crust expectoration and retching, with occasional occipital pain, while the cystic type presents with postnasal discharge, throat irritation, and cough.
        • The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, with no gender predilection and a peak incidence between 15 and 30 years.
        • A two-year clinicoanatomical audit at a rhinology practice identified six patients with nasopharyngeal bursitis, with an equal incidence of cystic and crust types.
        • The crust type may present with no symptoms other than retching and expectoration of crusts, and can develop at any age without recognized predisposing factors.
        • Histologically, the crust type shows reactive lymphoid mucosa with necrotic tissue, which may explain cicatricial streaks around the bursa.
        • Endoscopic interruption of the bursa with electrocauterization is a minimally invasive technique for treatment.
</summary>

<summary>
* The incidence of melanoma skin cancer has been increasing over the past decades.
    * Australia has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in the world.
    * Early diagnosis of melanoma is crucial for prognosis.
    * Dermoscopy is a noninvasive diagnostic technique that enhances visualization of morphological features.
    * Dermoscopy requires experience to differentiate skin lesions accurately.
    * Automated analysis of dermoscopic images is gaining interest to assist in diagnosis.
    * Computational intelligence methods can process data faster and more reliably.
    * A comprehensive review of automatic diagnostic models for skin lesions is needed.
    * The paper aims to summarize and compare advanced dermoscopic algorithms.
    * It discusses issues affecting classification success.
    * The paper provides a framework for selecting suitable algorithms for skin cancer diagnosis.
    * Performance evaluation measures and model validation details are presented.
    * Concluding comments are provided.
</summary>

<summary>
* *
    * The study aimed to assess the impact of paraoxonase-1 (pon1) and cyp2c19*2 polymorphisms on clopidogrel platelet inhibition in a North American study population of mixed racial background.
        * *
        * Platelet aggregation was measured using light transmittance aggregometry (LTA) and verifynow (VN) p2y12 assay.
            * *
            * The study included 96 subjects on maintenance clopidogrel therapy and 55 subjects who received a clopidogrel 600 mg loading dose at the time of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
                * *
                * Baseline characteristics were well balanced among genotype groups.
                    * *
                    * A higher prevalence of African-Americans was observed in carriers of pon1 qq192 genotype.
                        * *
                        * No significant differences in platelet aggregation or VN-p2y12 reactivity were found among pon1 genotypes.
                            * *
                            * Cyp2c19*2 carrier status was associated with reduced platelet inhibition and increased on-treatment platelet reactivity.
                                * *
                                * In multivariate analysis, cyp2c19*2 carrier status was significantly associated with platelet aggregation, while pon1 q192r genotype was not.
                                    * *
                                    * The study confirms the impact of cyp2c19*2 polymorphism on clopidogrel platelet inhibition and suggests that pon1 q192r polymorphisms are not predictive of clopidogrel response.
* *
</summary>

<summary>
    • The study evaluates characteristics and potential determinants of partial remission (PR) in type 1 diabetes (T1D) according to the new definition based on insulin-dose-adjusted HbA1c (IDAA1c) levels.
        • PR was observed in 56.2% of patients, with no complete remission cases.
            • PR duration was 9.2 months on average, with no significant differences between gender and age subgroups.
            • PR mostly occurred within the first 6 months, with 71.6% of patients experiencing PR shorter than 1 year.
            • PR duration was shorter in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis.
    • Lower baseline HbA1c (a1c) levels at diagnosis were associated with higher chances of PR.
            • Girls had lower a1c levels at diagnosis when entering PR, and a1c levels negatively correlated with longer PR durations in this subgroup.
            • Younger patients (0-4 years) had a1c levels at diagnosis correlating negatively with longer PR durations.
            • Higher baseline c-peptide levels were observed in boys entering PR compared to patients without PR.
    • C-peptide secretion was significantly different in PR versus non-PR patients until 3 years after diagnosis.
            • Higher baseline c-peptide levels were observed in boys entering PR and in older children at diagnosis.
            • C-peptide levels at diagnosis were not significantly associated with higher chances of PR.
    • PR duration or a1c+2y levels did not correlate with occurrence of severe hypoglycemia.
            • No differences in PR duration or a1c+2y levels were observed between patients with and without severe hypoglycemia.
            • Only a few patients developed diabetes-related complications during follow-up, showing no differences in PR duration or a1c+2y levels.
    • Long-term effects of PR on metabolic control and complications are unclear due to low numbers of events.
            • Short-term effect of PR on metabolic control was suggested in patients with PR durations between 510 and

<summary>
    • The study aimed to evaluate the relationship between objectively quantified sedentary behavior, habitual physical activity, and levels of visceral adiposity and intrahepatic lipid in adults with overweight/obesity.
        • Despite traditional risk factors for cardiovascular disease being associated with visceral adiposity and intrahepatic lipid, objectively measured physical activity and sedentary behavior did not predict these levels.
        • The study suggests that while traditional risk factors may predict the incidence of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease or high levels of visceral adiposity, objectively quantified physical activity and sedentary behavior do not significantly predict these conditions.
</summary>

* *
    * The study is a retrospective, observational, consecutive case series of firecracker injuries documented over a 5-day period during Diwali over the past 5 years at a tertiary eye care hospital in North India.
    * The study included patients of all ages and all cases who presented to the hospital during the 5 days of Diwali in the past 5 years.
* *
    * The study found that serious ocular injuries often occur due to the sudden appearance of unpredictable firecrackers before a person can deploy any defense mechanism.
    * The most common types of firecrackers causing injury were bombs, and high-velocity fireworks such as rockets and bombs were more frequently associated with facial lacerations, intraocular foreign bodies, endophthalmitis, and poorer visual outcomes.
    * The study also found that a significant percentage of patients end up losing their vision due to firework-related eye injuries, with 5 eyes eventually developing phthisis bulbi.
    * The study concluded that immediate measures such as prohibiting the manufacture and sale of dangerous fireworks, along with public awareness and expert primary ophthalmic care, are required to reduce this preventable cause of ocular morbidity.
